If an individual is inclined to take advantage of their fellow humans, they will quickly learn that just because something is not illegal doesn't mean they can get away with it. That lesson will be learned from others' mistakes.

replies.author: @podunkest
replies.text: @TheFredmac I take your point but there's a lot of people who could and would get away with a lot more shit if the simple threat of actual state sanctioned punishment was removed. And if someone gets away with a crime you won't ever know it happened nor would they be dealt with by society because they got away. People aren't going to do the leg work to catch average, small time criminals, nor do they have the resources to do it  thoroughly and correctly. Criminals, for the most part, will prey on the weak and most vulnerable, they aren't going to go after the people who can defend or avenge their transgressions. And I wouldn't say it's "designed" to protect criminals from society, it's designed to protect the integrity of the concept of Justice and to dissuade and deincentivize immoral behavior. And vigilantism, although very gratifying and satisfying, is often as wrong as it is right. I think the Justice system is designed to protect everyone from everything in theory, it's just not perfect nor will it ever be, but it sure could be a hell of a lot better. I appreciate Libertarian and Anarchist ideas in theory and on paper, but in practice they fall flat because they make far too many positive assumptions about the average human or how things will magically self-correct.

author: @GeneRic01
text:
The anti Asian spike. Did you know that in many US jurisdictions  in 2020, orders  were given to check over police databases and see whether any previous crimes could be recategorised as anti-Asian? 
More generally, many databases  had an extra anti-Asian tag _added_ to the system as a unique category, aside from the catchall HC definition.
So how much of that 2020 spike 'based upon actual statistics' really was part of a sudden increase and how much was 'suddenly choosing to notice'?
My belief is that most of those crimes _were happening all along_ and  have been growing for years, but it simply wasn't politic to notice until Trump said the magic word:
 "Chy-nah".

text:
If you have the time, as I do, you can go around the nation and visit local news channel's reports on crime and gain a pretty good feeling about what is actually going on. In city after city they are raising the alarm about the spike in Youth Crime and changing their laws to address it where the Politicians aren't standing in the way. As an example, the DC Council's rewrite of the Law Code was shot down by the GOP in Congress--and now the city is seeking to increase incarceration and penalties for Juveniles--which is the exact opposite of the direction their rewrite attempted to impose. Everywhere the criminal codes were softened for Juveniles there has been a huge spike in Juvenile offenses. Sam Seder and Emma Vigeland just cannot admit that they have been so wrong for so long.
Love,
David

author: @lostboy8084
text: Worked doing statistical analysis which taking the sample data from a small or large sample and then using it to figure out various conclusions. One of the most fundamental things you will find is data manipulation is very easy.  For example crime rates in a city just say you want to see a drop in the percentage. You will take your multiple crime population samples from different areas and they can be a large sample or small sample size which can also determine the statistical data. You take the data samples in the city where you know know there is lesser crime in that area.  Now supposed to be randomly but that just means you don't see the data but you can generally figure out how to do it and even then with the power of mathematically manipulation you can adjust the things so the answer which is what is seen how accurate of a prediction which is what statistical data analysis is is it 90% accurate with a 10% error or maybe 80% accurate with a 20% error one may show a jump in  crime while the other will show a drop in crime.  Funny enough the full raw data may even give a total different answer. Especially depending on where you get the data. For example say murder is it actually raw murder thay police cases, or murder based on court cases, or murder based on conviction and sent to prison.  I can pretty much assure you that one of these raw data will allow me to truthfully state something as factual never having to lie about murder being down.

author: @ImAnIslandBoy
text: I have first hand experience with this working for the criminal justice system in Illinois. They love to say our juvenile recidivism rate went down from 60 to 20% and our juvenile prison population went from several thousand to only 150 in the entire state. Won't they won't tell you is they've changed the laws making prosecutors exhaust all options (restorative justice bs) before sending kids to juvenile prison, and made the standards of evidence much more difficult so judges will commonly dismiss the charges or lower them, so I'll now see kids with 10-15 violent crime charges before they are ever sent to us. They've also put no cap on the amount of cut time you can get so kids will be out within 4-6 months so the population is always low. To make it even better they've changed the laws for parole, where as before if you had several violations your sent back to juvie. Now kids can pretty much violate all their conditions of parole with zero consequences and will only come back to us if they're officially charged with a crime. So our department loves to brag about recidivism is declining and so is the prison population but in reality it's because they changed the laws and this is the trend in a majority of the states. It's pretty insane the state of Illinois has less than 200 juveniles in prison but yet in Chicago you'll see hundreds of juvenile crime stories on the news within a month. That should tell you something doesn't smell right.
